CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-3 - Length of pre-trial detention);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Review of lawfulness of detention)
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested on suspicion of murder .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( ORG ) ordered his detention as a preventive measure pending trial , for an initial period of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the same court extended the applicant ’s pre - trial detention for DATE on the ground that there was a considerable volume of investigative measures to be carried out and there were no reasons for changing the preventive measure .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the investigation was completed and the applicant and his lawyer received access to the case file .
CARDINAL . On DATE another set of criminal proceedings was instituted against the applicant , for infliction of grievous bodily harm .
CARDINAL . On DATE the CARDINAL criminal cases were joined .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( ORG ) extended the applicant ’s pre - trial detention to DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was referred to ORG , which held a preliminary hearing on DATE . It ordered the applicant ’s further detention without fixing any time - limits .

CARDINAL . ORG remitted the case for further investigation CARDINAL times ( on DATE , as well as on DATE and DATE ) . The appellate court quashed the first CARDINAL decisions ( on DATE and CARDINAL DATE ) , but upheld the last one ( on DATE ) . All the judicial rulings in question maintained the applicant ’s continued detention without further reasoning .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation was completed and the case was referred for trial , this time to ORG as a first - instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a preliminary hearing , at which it decided , among other things , to remit the case for further investigation once again and to maintain the applicant ’s detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the above decision in so far as it concerned the remittal issue and rejected the applicant ’s request for release on the ground that he was accused of serious crimes .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of murder and attempted murder and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld that judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released following the legislative amendments pertaining to the enforcement of sentences .
